words.meaning: To cause an audience to applaud enthusiastically and loudly.
examples: The comedian's hilarious routine brought down the house.
Her powerful opera performance brought down the house on opening night.

words.meaning: To base something on weak or unstable foundations; to be based on an unstable or unreliable foundation.
examples: Their business plan was built upon sand, with no solid market research.
Any attempt to build a lasting peace without addressing the root causes of conflict is to build upon sand.

words.meaning: To work or study late into the night.
examples: She had to burn the midnight oil to finish her report on time.
Students often burn the midnight oil before exams.

words.meaning: To win a contest, argument, or election; to be victorious.
examples: Despite strong opposition, her arguments eventually carried the day.
The underdog team managed to carry the day in the final minutes of the game.

words.meaning: To be kept waiting for a period of time.
examples: I had to cool my heels in the waiting room for over an hour.
He was left to cool his heels while the manager was on a long phone call.

words.meaning: To be beneficial or pleasing, especially in a way that makes one feel better emotionally.
examples: Seeing all the volunteers helping out truly did my heart good.
A long walk in nature always does her heart good.

words.meaning: To become less aggressive or assertive; to reduce one's demands or ambitions.
examples: After losing the debate, he had to draw in his horns and compromise.
The company had to draw in its horns after several failed ventures.

words.meaning: To apologize and accept humiliation.
examples: After his prediction was wrong, he had to eat humble pie.
She had to eat humble pie when her supposed facts were proven incorrect.

words.meaning: To make money for oneself, often dishonestly or unfairly, especially when in a position of trust.
examples: The corrupt official used his position to feather his own nest.
Some politicians are accused of feathering their nests at public expense.

words.meaning: To waste effort on something that is no longer possible or relevant.
examples: Trying to convince him now is just flogging a dead horse.
Continuing the debate is flogging a dead horse; the decision has been made.

words.word: to get off one's high horse
words.meaning: To stop acting in a superior or arrogant manner.
examples: It's time for him to get off his high horse and listen to others.
She needs to get off her high horse and accept that she made a mistake.

words.meaning: To become angry or annoyed.
examples: His rude comment really got my back up.
Don't get your back up; I was only trying to help.

words.meaning: To be dismissed from employment.
examples: He got the sack for consistently arriving late to work.
If you keep making mistakes, you'll get the sack.

words.word: to get up on the wrong side of the bed
words.meaning: To be in a bad mood, for no apparent reason.
examples: He's been grumpy all morning; he must have gotten up on the wrong side of the bed.
Don't mind her; she just got up on the wrong side of the bed today.

words.meaning: To come to nothing; to be ruined or destroyed.
examples: All their plans went up in smoke when the funding was cut.
Years of hard work went up in smoke after the fire.

words.meaning: To have readily available and easily accessible.
examples: He had all the necessary information at his fingertips.
With the internet, you can have a vast amount of knowledge at your fingertips.

words.word: to hit the nail on the head
words.meaning: To describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem.
examples: When you said she was feeling overwhelmed, you really hit the nail on the head.
His analysis hit the nail on the head, accurately identifying the core issue.

words.word: to lay one's cards on the table
words.meaning: To reveal one's plans or intentions openly and honestly.
examples: It's time we laid our cards on the table and discussed our true feelings.
The negotiation began with both sides laying their cards on the table.

words.meaning: To try every possible course of action in order to achieve something.
examples: The detective vowed to leave no stone unturned in the search for the missing child.
We'll leave no stone unturned to find a solution to this problem.

words.meaning: To treat (a person) as a celebrity; to give a lot of public attention and approval to (someone).
examples: After winning the award, he was lionized by the media and the public.
The town decided to lionize its war heroes with a parade.

words.word: to live in a fool's paradise
words.meaning: To be happy because one is unaware of potential trouble.
examples: He's living in a fool's paradise if he thinks he can pass the exam without studying.
The company was living in a fool's paradise, ignoring the signs of impending financial trouble.

words.meaning: To keep things as they are; to prevent change.
examples: The conservative party sought to maintain the status quo.
Some people resist innovation because they prefer to maintain the status quo.

words.meaning: To earn just enough money to live on.
examples: With two part-time jobs, she barely managed to make ends meet.
Rising inflation makes it harder for many families to make ends meet.

words.word: to make the best of a bad bargain
words.meaning: To make the most of a difficult or undesirable situation.
examples: The car broke down, but we decided to make the best of a bad bargain and enjoy the walk.
It wasn't the job she wanted, but she resolved to make the best of a bad bargain.

words.meaning: To bear the unpleasant consequences of one's actions.
examples: He enjoyed his reckless spending, but eventually, he had to pay the piper.
If you break the rules, you'll eventually have to pay the piper.

words.meaning: To pretend to be dead or unconscious in order to deceive someone.
examples: The fox played possum when the hunters approached.
He wasn't really asleep; he was just playing possum to avoid chores.

words.word: to pour oil on troubled waters
words.meaning: To calm a tense or difficult situation.
examples: She stepped in to pour oil on troubled waters and mediate the argument.
His calming words helped to pour oil on troubled waters during the heated discussion.

words.meaning: To do one's fair share of work.
examples: Everyone in the team needs to pull their own weight for the project to succeed.
He's not pulling his own weight, and it's affecting the whole group.

words.meaning: To move to a different place.
examples: After graduation, they decided to pull up stakes and move to a new city.
The family pulled up stakes and relocated for a better job opportunity.

words.meaning: To create a loud disturbance; to cause trouble.
examples: If they don't fix this problem, I'm going to go down there and raise Cain.
The children were raising Cain in the backyard, making a lot of noise.

words.word: to rub a person the wrong way
words.meaning: To annoy or irritate someone.
examples: His condescending attitude always rubs me the wrong way.
Her sarcastic comments tend to rub people the wrong way.

words.meaning: To be in charge; to be the dominant person in a group or household.
examples: In that family, the youngest child seems to rule the roost.
She's a strong leader who rules the roost in her department.

words.meaning: To reveal one's intentions, plans, or resources.
examples: He tried to keep his strategy secret, but eventually, he had to show his hand.
The company didn't want to show its hand too early in the negotiations.

words.meaning: To indulge in a period of reckless, irresponsible, and often promiscuous behavior, typically as a young person.
examples: Before settling down, he spent a few years sowing his wild oats.
She encouraged her son to experience life but warned him not to sow too many wild oats.

words.meaning: To reveal a secret or tell something that was supposed to be kept secret.
examples: Don't spill the beans about the surprise party!
He accidentally spilled the beans about their secret plans.

words.meaning: To argue about very small differences or unimportant details.
examples: Let's not split hairs over minor disagreements; focus on the main goal.
The lawyer was known for splitting hairs in court.

words.word: to strike while the iron is hot
words.meaning: To take advantage of an opportunity when it arises.
examples: The housing market is favorable, so it's time to strike while the iron is hot and buy a house.
She decided to apply for the job immediately, striking while the iron was hot.

words.word: to take a leaf out of someone's book
words.meaning: To imitate someone in a particular way because you admire them or want to be like them.
examples: I'm going to take a leaf out of his book and start exercising regularly.
She decided to take a leaf out of her successful mentor's book.

words.meaning: To conquer or capture a place quickly. To be overwhelmingly successful or popular in a particular place or among a particular group of people.
examples: The new band took the music scene by storm.
The army managed to take the fortress by storm.

words.meaning: To humble someone; to make someone less arrogant or conceited.
examples: His recent failure really took him down a peg.
Someone needs to take that arrogant guy down a peg or two.

words.meaning: To leave without permission or without saying goodbye.
examples: He took French leave from the party without anyone noticing.
The soldier was reprimanded for taking French leave from his post.

words.meaning: To look after and guide someone who is less experienced.
examples: The experienced mentor took the new employee under her wing.
He took the young, aspiring artist under his wing, offering guidance and support.

words.word: to tell tales out of school
words.meaning: To reveal private or confidential information about someone or something.
examples: Don't tell tales out of school; what happens in this office stays in this office.
She got into trouble for telling tales out of school about her colleagues.

words.meaning: To discourage or dampen enthusiasm for something.
examples: His negative comments always throw cold water on everyone's ideas.
Don't throw cold water on her dreams; let her try.

words.meaning: To issue a challenge.
examples: The rival team threw down the gauntlet, challenging them to a final match.
The politician threw down the gauntlet, daring his opponent to a debate.

words.word: to throw the book at someone
words.meaning: To punish someone very severely for an offense.
examples: The judge threw the book at him for repeated reckless driving.
If you break the law again, they'll throw the book at you.

words.meaning: To spend less money than usual because there is less available.
examples: With the recent layoffs, many families are having to tighten their belts.
We'll need to tighten our belts if we want to save for a vacation.

words.meaning: To attack imaginary enemies or to fight against impossible odds.
examples: He's always tilting at windmills, pursuing unrealistic goals.
Trying to change the entire system by himself feels like tilting at windmills.

words.meaning: To conform to a rule or standard; to obey or comply.
examples: New employees are expected to toe the mark and follow company policies.
If he doesn't toe the mark, he'll face consequences.

words.meaning: To manipulate or control someone completely and effortlessly.
examples: She can twist her father around her little finger to get whatever she wants.
He's so charming, he can twist anyone around his finger.

words.meaning: To spoil a plan or arrangement.
examples: His sudden resignation really upset the apple cart for the entire project.
Don't upset the apple cart by bringing up that controversial topic now.

words.meaning: To cover up or gloss over faults or wrongdoings.
examples: The government was accused of trying to whitewash the scandal.
They attempted to whitewash the company's negative image with a new advertising campaign.

words.meaning: A person who praises and helps powerful people in order to get their approval.
examples: He was known as a toady, always flattering the boss.
She despised the toadies who surrounded the famous celebrity.

words.meaning: A thing serving as a tangible representation of a fact, quality, feeling, etc. Something that represents something else, often as a gesture.
examples: Please accept this small gift as a token of my appreciation.
He wore a token of remembrance from his travels.

words.meaning: To allow the existence, occurrence, or practice of (something that one does not necessarily like or agree with) without interference. To endure (something unpleasant or difficult) without complaining.
examples: I can't tolerate rude behavior.
Some plants can tolerate extreme temperatures.

words.meaning: A book, especially a large, heavy, scholarly one.
examples: He spent hours studying the ancient tome of forgotten spells.
The professor's office was filled with dusty tomes on various subjects.

words.meaning: Expressing something in a way that appears to be serious but is actually playful or ironic.
examples: He made a tongue-in-cheek comment about his own cooking skills.
Her entire performance was delivered with a delightful tongue-in-cheek humor.

words.meaning: A medicinal substance taken to give a feeling of vigor or well-being. A stimulating or invigorating effect.
examples: The fresh air was a real tonic after being stuck indoors all day.
She felt the natural tonic of the mountain spring water.

words.meaning: The state of normal tension in living muscles, or in living tissues generally. The osmotic pressure of a solution, usually relative to that of blood.
examples: The doctor assessed the tonicity of the patient's muscles.
Maintaining proper fluid tonicity is essential for cellular function.

words.meaning: (Of food) delicious or appetizing. (Of a person) attractive or pleasing.
examples: The bakery offered a display of toothsome pastries.
He enjoyed the toothsome flavor of the homemade stew.
